thread.title: Live cattle exports hit record high
thread.title_full: Live cattle exports hit record high

title: Live cattle exports hit record high
text:
View Photo 

Exports of live cattle reached a record 1.38 million head last financial year, an increase of 22 per cent. 
The latest figures from Meat and Livestock Australia show the value of the exports at $1.4 billion, up 29 per cent - though there is an expectation 2015-16 will not be so bountiful. 
Indonesia was again the main destination, taking 746,193 head, an increase of 20 per cent. 
However Indonesia may be cutting imports of Australian cattle after the government slashed its third quarter quota by 80 per cent. 
But there are indications that quota may rise in response to soaring retail beef prices. 
Vietnam was Australia's second biggest market, taking 309,505 head, a rise of 136 per cent. 
Other markets eased. Chinese imports dropped 15 per cent to 79,517, though there are hopes that will increase substantially under the China-Australia free trade agreement. 
Exports of live sheep reached almost 2.2 million, an increase of nine per cent. 
The overall value reached $244 million, a 32 per cent increase. 
Most of the sheep - 97 per cent - go to the Middle East. 
Quantities to individual countries varied - reduced exports to Kuwait, Jordan and Qatar were more than offset by increases to the UAE and Bahrain. 
Exports of whole sheep carcasses to the Middle East also increased, to almost 80,000 tonnes. 
Australian Livestock Exporters' Council chief executive Alison Penfold said the industry is seeking to find other markets and improve animal welfare as the exports increase. 
"Industry continues to invest in improving practices and productivity," she said in a statement. @y7finance on Twitter, become a fan on Facebook Live cattle exports hit record high AAP
